Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting Prof. Gregory B. Dudley of Florida State University to develop new methods for the synthesis and strategic application of alkynes. The alkyne functional group is becoming increasingly prominent as chemists place greater emphasis on conservation (atom economy), efficiency (step economy), and simplicity (click chemistry). New methods for alkyne synthesis are needed to fuel the growth of modern alkyne chemistry. The research efforts at Florida State University will focus on de novo creation of CC triple bonds by fragmentation, retro-cycloaddition, and other entropically favorable processes. Special emphasis will be placed on the synthesis of alkynes that are needed for specific applications in the molecular sciences but that cannot be prepared by direct substitution of acetylene. Strategic applications of the resulting alkynes will be developed as an integral part of the research process, including the chemical synthesis of bioactive natural products and of strained cycloalkynes of relevance to bioorthogonal chemistry. The strained cycloalkynes will be designed and evaluated in collaboration with the co PI, Prof. Igor Alabugin of Florida State University.

Alkynes are high energy hydrocarbons containing triple bonds. The impact of alkyne chemistry transcends traditional boundaries of chemical synthesis. Alkyne chemical reactions are instrumental to many techniques in bioimaging, pharmaceutical synthesis, advanced materials research, etc. These techniques therefore depend on convenient access to the requisite alkynes. The proposed research is expected to lead to more efficient production of high-value alkynes and to a better fundamental understanding of alkyne reactivity. This research program is fully integrated with university education efforts. The organic methodology and synthesis research opportunities associated with this project will prepare student participants to excel in an innovation-based economy. Science communication is an important part of this preparation. In addition to disseminating research results to the scientific community, program participants communicate broadly with the public, including K-12 students, through various outreach programs. These programs target local and global audiences to promote awareness of the increasingly global, diverse, and multidisciplinary chemical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical synthesis – the ability to create and manipulate molecular structures – is an extremely powerful technology that enables advances in medicine, materials, energy, and other grand societal challenges. This project in chemical synthesis focused on the synthesis and enabling utility of molecular structures known as alkynes. “Alkynes” are characterized by having a triple bond between carbon atoms at some point in the molecular structure. Acetylene (C2H2) is the best known and archetypal example. Indeed, most alkynes used in chemical synthesis are made from acetylene, which itself is produced in high-energy petroleum refining processes. Very few alkynes occur naturally, which is both a challenge and an opportunity for alkyne chemistry. Success with this project required new strategies for creating the carbon–carbon triple bond within the context of pre-existing complex molecular structures.

Research focused on chemical reactions known as fragmentations, in which larger ring-containing structures were strategically broken open in characteristic ways. In the cases at hand, these fragmentation reactions produced various types of alkynes that would be difficult to make by other means. Alkynes tethered to alkenes (characterized by carbon–carbon double bonds) were prepared to study and apply reactions between alkynes and alkenes, and several new reactions and/or advances in known reactions were developed as outcomes of this work. Alkynes incorporated strategically into ring structures were also prepared to study and apply reactions of such “cycloalkynes”, particularly those for which the ring structure is not ideal for incorporating an alkynes. These “strained cycloalkynes” have proven to be powerful tools for studying complex biochemical systems.

The overall product outcomes include important advances in the state of the art of chemical synthesis. New methods for preparing alkynes were developed, and the high-value alkynes thus produced were leveraged to prepare molecular structures of interest for future health and life science research.

There is additionally an important training and professional development component associated with research in chemical synthesis. Chemical synthesis is an empirical science grounded in a vast body of prior experiments and observations. It provides excellent experiential learning opportunities for the next generation of scientists to excel in the global innovation-based economy. The hands-on laboratory research for this project was developed and carried out by a team of graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral scientists. Rigorous application of the Scientific Method, careful experimentation, thoughtful analysis, and critical assessment skills are all refined and improved through the immersive research experiences in chemical synthesis that were central to this project.


Last Modified: 01/07/2019
Modified by: Gregory B Dudley
